document.text: Yesterday morning shortly before 7 oclock, at her home on Eightn  street, Mrs. J . T . Gills was painfully, though not seriously, burned by an explosion of a gas stor--. In some way or other gas from one of the burners had leaked into the j the Lynchburg bar where it had accumulated and when T_ ,, n she opened the door of the oven the imprisoned gar caught fire from the J burner and immediately there was Ian explosion which threw Mrs. Gills backward. Her hair was singed and her face was considerably burned. Later on her injuries were treated by Dr. Samuel Lyle- Lynchburg News, Jan . 28th.

The Youth Choir of the church also participated in the program. At the conclusion of the business session, Mrs. J. T. Irby presented a Life Membership certificate and pm to Mrs. C. W. Smith who has seived as leader of Circle No. 2 for futeen -years, and to Mrs. J. E. Sears who has been assistant leader. In the absence of Mrs. Sears, the awards were accepted by Mrs. Ivey Holland. document.text: Womens Missionary Society of liberty Baptist Church The Women Missionary Society of Liberty Baptist Church, or rather known first as the Ladie  Aid Society, was organized by Rev. Dr Henry W. Tribble in the year of his pastorate of this church, in 18 85. It was a small and feeble beginning but an earnest Christian spirit and effort tup ported the movement of this struggling band of Christian workers. Dr. Tribble even in vited the men to join the society so as to encourage and help the ladies in their Christian work Miss Sue Sears was elected president for several years, and she was active and efficient in the society, as in all other church work, wherever her consecrated life found work for the Heavenly Father Miss Sears best endeavors for His cause were always given I remember a few of the orig inal members Mrs. William H Gills, Mrs. William H. Abbitt Mrs. Joel Oawthorn, Mrs. T. A Caldwell, Mrs. C. W. Hancock Misses Sis OConner, Sis Ab bitt, and Lula Jones. This society met in the Amen corn er of the chnrch for years, after the regular monthly service on the 3rd Sunday of each month This society did much church work in individual ways, but rarely ever had any money, ex cept a few cents in the treasury. We tried lawn parties, lectures, oyster suppers, tableaux, etc. But rains, illness, or something seemed to break us up, minus of finances. If we raised fire or ten dollars a year for our society we thought we had done well, aa in those days ladies Ad minis- were not supposed to have any

document.text: with a poignant regret at the memory of the big fish that would haris wen the prize. But not for a moment was he sorry that he had cast In his lot with the dancing barrel. On board the Lance they were pull ing, discouraged and heartsick. The rope came in so easily th at they knew the dory could not be at its end. The probability was that Dixon had been unable to reach the buoy, and was drifting to leeward In his boat. It was more than doubtful if they ever saw him again. Dixoh felt th at he could hold on but little longer. Jhe power of thought had nearly been beaten out of him. He seemed to have been dragged for hours through the swash of the sea. His body was numbed al most to paralysis. A dozen times he had imagined the schooners light in the gloom to windward, but had found himself mistaken. He was pos sessed by a dull conviction that he would never reach her. An unwonted smoothness of the sea surprised himi He raised his head, and there, not thirty feet away, shone the lantern in the Lances fore rigging. As her deck rolled down, he saw the swaying line of weary men heaving in the rope. At the same instant they caught sight of him, and gave a shout of surprise and joy. Very carefully the last few feet were coiled in, until willing arms hauled him over the rail. Tucked in a bunk near the stove and filled with hot coffee, he tdld re gretfully of the record-breaking fish he had lost. At the end of his story two men went out. Presently they returned, carrying by the gills the biggest cod he had ever set eyes on. It was considerably over five feet long. Stand up, Chris! they shouted to a wiry little Cape Verde Islander, Suspended glistening in the lamp light, the monstdr came almost to the top of the Portuguese fishermans head. As Dixon looked, the bitter ness of loss went out of his heart. Good boy, Chris! said he. Im glad you got him. I dont feel halt so bad about losing mine, sined he couldnt have won the prize. Youths Companion.

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. H ., Bent j Creek. ChaP. Evergreen ForesLj Store, Hixburg, Mineral and Nebraska. And so the old records go on j . . . . an interesting account of  people and communities right j here . . .  right long ago. i A penny stamp no doubt could j  send the word to any of the county SEVENTEEN post of- ! fices Appomattox C . H., Bent j Creek, Chap, E v e r g r e e n , Fores Store, Hixburg, Mineral, Nebraska, Oakville, Old Pilot, Pamplin City, Reedy Springs, Rose Bwer, Spanish O a k s , Spout Spring, Spring Mills, Tower Hill. Almost any one of us might like to have some of those sta- wart farmers, merchants and other professional men and wo men among us again, but who can truly say that  they were the good old days. Speaking ed itorially, of course, THESE are the GOOD DAYS even if one doesnt particularly like frozen dinners or some of the current TV offerings.. . Penicillin, Jet travel, air conditioning, modern automobiles, Rescue Squads, radio stereophonic sound and pant suited comfort for the wo men are only a few of the many blessings of 1971. Anyone care to argue about that? Many trades and professions were represented back in those days. There were thirteen coach and wagonmakers, two dentists, eleven  Distillers , two drug gists, two florists and twenty- four merchants offering  Gen eral Merchandise . Four hotels served the county D. W. Gills, Pamplin City R. B. Harvey, Spring Mills, J . Walton Mc Kinney, A p p o m atto x Court House and J . R . Alwood, Ne braska. Land Agents included Dr. W. A. Hoseley, Mineral and A.B. White and Co., Bent Creek. Farmers could have their corn and flour ground at any one of thirteen mills, including mills operated or owned by A. F . An derson, Appomattox C. H. J .J .

document.text: week in Ivor.   , The senior class of the loteal school will sponsor a square dance at the town hall on Wed nesday-mght, April 27. C. W. Dickerson, state sup ervisor of Public School Libra ries, visited Appomattox high school this week. Miiha Frankie McKinney ex pects to return home this week after a visit to relatiyes in Lynchburg. - J. E. Dinwiddie and family are moving -into one of Mrs. At woods houses this week. Mrs. Sammie Furr, of West Virginia, is visiting her parents at the old court house. Mrs. Ola Patterson enter tained at a surprise dinner par ty for her daughter, Earle, Wednesday evening. The din ner guests were Misses Elaine McDearmon, Vara Morris, Kate OBrien and Messrs Cal vin H. Robinson, Harold Spen cer, Willitam T. Smith, George Abbitt. Mr. and Mrs. C. A- Hancock visited Mrs. Lillie Gregory last week. While here,. Mrs. Han- cock had new lighting fixtures put up in the post office build ing. - Several members of Dr- Christians family have b e e n sick during the last week, but are now out again. Mrs. E E- Gills, Mias Louise and brother,, Robert, returned with Mr. Jamie Gills to Blue- field for a visit. Miss Bessie Jeter, of Home Economics Department, S. T. C- Farmville, accompanied by her mother, visited Miss Florence Gregory last week-end. Robert Edward Lee chapter of U. D. C. met with Mrs. Kate OBrien on last Saturday night. Mrs- Evrod Connor was elected delegate to district meeting to be held in Chase City. Mrs. Dora Martin, of Farm ville, returned home Friday after spending a few days with Mrs. Charles E. Seay. Mrs. Hallie Ferguson of Vera spent a few days last week with her mother, Mrs. Charles E. Seay. Mrs. W. H. S. Barlow and son, Ralph, have returned home after a pleasant visit to rela tives in Clifton Forge. Mr. and Mrs. J. D. Morris, Miss Thelma. Morris, Mrs. Flo rence Bingham and William Moore visited relatives in Rich mond last Sunday. The Recreational Club heli its social for the month of Ap ril on Tuesday night. Enter tainment was in the form of a leap-year dance. Little Lester Hudgins enter tained a score of his little friends at his birthday party Tuesday. He was ten years old. Mr- and Mrs. K. O. Reid, of Richmond, stopped by to make a short visit to friends on Wed nesday. See Wilkes plant advertise ment.

document.text: Wayside, Jan. 4.- Mrs. F . A . OBrien, who was rushed back to Ljhe hospital last Thursday, is im proving slowly. Beryl Covington, who underwent an operation for appendicitis last Tuesday night is expected to return home Tuesday. Mr. and Mrs. R M Webb spent SBfiday with Mrs. R.fW.Morris. Those who called in the home of I F A . OBrien Sunday were Mrs. R W. Morris, Mr. and Mrs.R. M Webb, Miss Cornelia Gills, Mr. and Mrs. Banks Frazier, Mr. and Mrs J.H . OBrien and Mr. Graves. Mr. and Mrs. Boilte have moved into the cottage of Mrs. Mildred Alvis. Mrs. Alvii and Patricia have moved into the home of F. A. OBrien. Mr. and Mrs. Louis D hi and son, of Farmville spent las week end in the home of F. A. OBrien. Mrs. Bertha Gills spent a fsw days last week n Richmond James OBrien spent the week- 1 enJ with his father, J H OBrien. document.text: Wayside, Feb. 2.- Mrs. F. A. _ OBrien, who has been a patient in had been with Jesus and had le irn- the Virginia Baptist Hospital for ed of Him. Her good cheer, ready 1 the past month, returned to her sympathy, and radiant smile, were home Monday. the external evidences of her  Mrs. Gus Turnes and Mrs. W. deeply spiritual nature. Her kind-1 P. Gills have been sick with colds. ness extended to all classes and races. Many there are where she went along who rise up and call her blessed. Precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of His saints. It would be difficult indeed to compute the weight of her in fluence upon the young people whom she taught for many years in the Sunday School. For all who knew her dread age is past, She took life tip-toe fee the very last! It never lost for her its lovely look,

document.text: Wayside, Dec. I.- The W. M. U. of New Hope Church met in the home of Mrs F. A.OBrien Friday for the day, and observed the week of prayer for foreign missions. In the afternoon they had a quilting. Mrs. Banks Frazier has returned from the hospital to the home of her mother, Mrs. W. P. Gills. Miss Geòrgie McFadden was rush ed to the hospital Thursday. Misses Jacqueline Alvis ani Alic-sc Covington, of Richmond spent the holidays here with their parents. Mary Alice Webb was the guest of Aliese Covington. They all attended the football game Thursday in Roanoke. .The many friends of Mrs. George F. Abbitt, Sr., were glad to see her at church Sunday, after au extend ed illness. Miss Annie Torrence, of Farmville spent the holidays in the home of Gus Tumes, and accompanied Mr. and Mrs. Turnes and family to Roan oke for the week-end. document.text: Washington.What price sardines! In France Jnst now this Is more than a question of gustatory Interest The price of the little fishes has fallen so low that the discouraged fishermen and cannery workers of Brittany, the worlds chief source of sardines, are threatening Bolshevism, and have even elected commissars of the peo ple, according to press dispatches. Brittany and its leading Industry are the subjects of the following bulletin from Washington D. C. headquar ters of the National Geographic so ciety. For more reasons than one- Brit tany might be called the Ireland of France,  says the bulletin. The Bretons are Celts, cousins of the Irish. They have the same Interest in things of the spirit, and the same tendency, on occasion, to emotional outbursts. For centuries, too, they had the same antagonism toward outside rule that so long animated the Irish. For 1,500 years they fought successfully against Roman, Norman, English and French, for the Independence of Brittany. They managed to keep a parliament of their own until the French revolu tion. Has Frances Beat Harbors. Today Brittany has no political ex istence, and is not even represented on many maps. It occupies the spout of the French teapot. the western most peninsula of France, the north ern coast of which forms the south ern mouth of the English channel. This land, about the size of Maryland, was formerly Armorica, but got its present name during the Fifth and Sixth centuries because of the heavy Immigration of Britons, driven from across the channel by the Angles and Saxons. It is a rough country, cov ered with rocks and hills and semi mountains. Its coast line Is deeply Indented, and has the best harbors in France. This fact and the existence of large numbers of fish offshore, - turned the eyes of the Bretons sea ward. They are Frances greatest fishermen and her chief reliance as material for her navy and merchant marine. Many sorts of fish and sea food are taken in Brittany waters, but by far the leading product Is the sardine. Brittanys sardine industry began to develop in 1845 when the first can nery was built. This was not long after the preservation of food prod ucts by canning had been placed on a sound basis. Now there are more than 200 canneries in the region. The sar dine fishermen number 30,000 or more, and some 20,000 workers, mostly girls and women, are engaged in the pack ing industry The prosperity of Brittany binges on the Uttle fish, and it is fickle tn its favors. Some years there will be practically none in the offshore wa ters, and as many as four poor years have followed one another. When this happens there is real suffering at times 80,000 people have been prac tically on the verge of starvation, and the French government has bad to lend a hand. The sardines are taken in nets in the meshes of which they are caught by their gills. It is necessary, how ever, to use large quantities of bait, salted cod eggs. When a school of sardines appears near a fishing boat, bait is thrown beyond the dangling net, and the little fishes rushing for the falling food, are snared in the meshes. The net is then lifted aboard and the fish gently shaken out. The fishing takes place near shore and often the fish are in the canneries within an hour or so after they are taken from the water. The fishermen sell by the thousand, according to size, the larger fish bring ing the best price. Brices range from one dollar to five per thousand ac cording to conditions. The cannery workers go through a complicated procedure. They cleun and behead the little flsnes, sonk them in brine, dry them in wire baskets, Immerse the baskets of fishes in boiling oil, pack the sardines in tin boxes, pour in oil, seal the boxes, and finully boll them in huge cauldrons of water for two hours. The boxes are then labeled and are ready for market . Prehistoric Monuments. Inland Brittany Is an agricultural ! country, but much of the land Is in fertile. There are numerous wild i moorlands. On these are some of the 1 most interesting prehistoric remains found in Europe, the rough stone , monuments of the early Celts. Huge stones have been stood on end. These are known as menhirs. When they have been placed in circles or arcs as in the British Stonehenge made also by Celts at about the same time they are called cromlechs. When the . great upright stones support horizon-  tal ones they are dolmens. The most ! striking of these monuments are the 1 alignments of menhirs.  The early Celts are supposed to ibave erected the stones in connection ! with their religious rites, and appar ently the great Carnac alignment was I a sort of Mecca and a holy burial 1 place. Keystones in the cromlechs j were oriented with regard to certain  seasonal positions of the sun. This  has furnished a clew for astronomers i and archeologists working together, 1 and they have computed the approxi mate building date of the oldest mon uments at 2000 B. C. The latest of the monuments were probably erected during the first century, B. C.
